before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"be4rm","text":"Before Start","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b4eq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f1k7m","text":"We use 50-75 million bloodstream parasites per sample. Parasites are cultured in HMI9 media with incubation at  and 5% CO2. Cultures should be prepared in advance so that sufficient numbers of parasites are available for each sample. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":121,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":111,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"atf06","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11jok","text":"The protocol works best when everything is kept cold prior to cutting with the protein A-MNase fusion protein. We recommend keeping buffers chilled on ice and pre-cooling centrifuges to  . Protease inhibitors should be added to the NP-S buffer just before commencing the experiment. The amount of 2X Stop Buffer required for the experiment should be calculated and yeast spike-in DNA should be added prior to starting (see 2X Stop Buffer recipe below).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":297,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":186,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8nerj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"37","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"5E1547800F2A11EE9A613F45FCB05DC8","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4-10","unit":10}}}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"eekgj","text":"This Cleavage Under Targets and Release Using Nuclease (CUT\u0026RUN) protocol produces genomic occupancy data for a protein of interest in the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma brucei. The data produced is analyzed in a similar way as that produced by ChIP-seq. While we describe the protocol for parasites carrying an epitope tag for the protein of interest, antibodies against the native protein could be used for the same purpose. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":158,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"1natk","text":"Guidelines","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f09pq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2tl3e","text":"Pay extra attention to time-sensitive incubation periods, particularly the DNA cleavage step. We find that working through the protocol rather speedily produces the best results, so don’t dawdle. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8307p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"151r9","text":"Additional Notes","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8rgbc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b22ao","text":"We keep our centrifuges at   to make sure the samples don’t freeze if the temperature drifts slightly. All spin steps of the protocol can be performed anywhere between   and  .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":27,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":168,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":174,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4sdd4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fr8so","text":"While we have not rigorously tested whether increasing the exposure time to saponin influences permeabilization, we recommend that the saponin permeabilization step be completed in smaller batches of samples if large numbers of samples\n(\u003e10) are being processed simultaneously.\n","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6j4n0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"56A019800F2A11EE9A613F45FCB05DC8","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"10","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"51C98B300F2A11EE9A613F45FCB05DC8","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10}},"2":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"5396AA100F2A11EE9A613F45FCB05DC8","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"10","unit":10}}}}
